reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s optimism about reaching mostly-great futures via trade/compromise and “collective decision-making processes,” which is an important (though not exclusive) pillar of the overall position; the essay also leans on arguments about (non-)convergence and blockers, so refuting the trade-mechanism talk would weaken but not fully collapse the thesis (moderate centrality). The critique mainly argues that the essay lacks formal mechanism specification, incentive-compatibility analysis, and feasibility results; this is a real methodological gap, but it doesn’t establish that such mechanisms can’t exist or that the essay’s conditional claims are false, so it only modestly weakens the relevant parts (low–moderate strength). Factual claims are mostly correct (no formal mechanism, no proofs), though overstated in places (the essay does gesture at concrete candidates like Nash bargaining, majority rule, institutions/iron-clad contracts, and discusses threats/power concentration), reducing correctness somewhat. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, with little fluff beyond rhetorical framing.
title: Appeals to bargaining mechanisms lack formal specification and proofs
